start.title:
Falling Into Orbit

The Mathematics of Spaceflight
start.description: Join Ayaan and Leila, two curious cadets selected for an elite space training program, as they learn the mathematics behind rockets and orbits from Dr. Vega. In this STEAMQuest, you'll explore how ancient mathematics predicts modern spaceflight—from parabolic projectiles to orbital paths—and discover that getting to space isn't about going up, it's about going sideways fast enough to keep falling and missing the Earth.

S2_D1_FX_C0.heading: Welcome to Starlight Space Camp
S2_D1_FX_C0.body: Where young explorers train like astronauts. Today, we will discover the science behind rockets, orbits, and space travel, learning how mathematics guides every step of the journey. Ready to discover the hidden mathematics and science behind rockets and orbits?

S3.S3_D1_FX_C1: Cadets, for thousands of years humans gazed at the stars and wondered: could we ever reach them? Tell me — what do you already know about space?
S3.S3_D2_FX_C3: There's no air. You float around. And there's no gravity!
S3.S3_D3_FX_C2: Not exactly, Ayaan. There is gravity in space — it's what keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C1: Correct, Leila. What vanishes in space isn't gravity — it's air.
S3.S3_D5_FX_C1: Now, another question: how far away is space?
S3.S3_D6_FX_C3: Super far. Like thousands of miles?
S3.S3_D7_FX_C1: Not at all. Space begins just 62 miles up — if you could drive straight up, you'd be there in under an hour.
S3.S3_D8_FX_C2: Wait… then why is it so hard to reach? Why can't an airplane just fly there?
S3.S3_D9_FX_C1: Ah, now we're asking the right question. It's not about going up — it's about going fast enough sideways.

S4.S4_D1_FX_C1: Before we launch anything into orbit, we need to understand the basics. Every object you throw follows a curved path — a parabola.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C3: A parabola? Like those U-shaped graphs from math class?
S4.S4_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. Whether you're throwing a ball or launching a rocket, gravity bends the path into a curve described by a simple equation: y equals a x squared plus bx plus cy = ax² + bx + c.
S4.S4_D4_FX_C2: So the values of a, b and c in the equation determine the shape of the curve?
S4.S4_D5_FX_C1: Precisely. The angle you launch at and the speed you use change those values — and change the path. Let's test this with our projectile simulator.

about.heading: Projectile Motion Simulator
about.body:
Understanding Projectile Motion:

  1. Parabolic Trajectory: All projectiles follow a curved path called a parabola, described by the equation y equals a x squared plus bx plus cy = ax² + bx + c.
  2. Launch Angle Effect: Shallow angles (closer to 0°) create longer horizontal distances, while steep angles (closer to 90°) create higher maximum heights.
  3. Velocity Effect: Higher initial velocities result in longer ranges and greater maximum heights, but the projectile always follows a parabolic path back to Earth.
  4. Gravity's Role: Gravity constantly pulls the projectile downward, creating the characteristic curved trajectory that always returns to the ground.

help.heading: How to use this Simulator?
help.body:
To explore projectile motion physics:

  1. Adjust the Launch Angle slider (0° to 89°) to change the trajectory shape
  2. Modify the Initial Velocity slider (3.33 to 328.1 ft/s) to change projectile speed
  3. Observe how the Trajectory Formula updates automatically with your changes
  4. Click Fire to launch the projectile and watch its path
  5. Use Reset to clear the simulation and start over

S5.S5_D1_FX_C1: Here's your first mission: launch a projectile and watch how it moves. Adjust the launch angle slider and observe how the trajectory changes.
S5.S5_D2_FX_C2: Oh! At shallow angles, it travels farther horizontally. At steep angles, it goes higher but lands closer.
S5.S5_D3_FX_C1: Excellent observation. Now adjust the velocity slider. Try launching at different speeds.
S5.S5_D4_FX_C3: The faster it goes, the farther it travels! So if I just crank up the speed all the way, I will launch it into orbit?
S5.S5_D5_FX_C1: Go ahead, Ayaan. Set the velocity to maximum and fire. What happens?
S5.S5_D6_FX_C3: Whoa! It goes really far... but it still comes back down. It always curves back to Earth.
S5.S5_D7_FX_C2: No matter how fast we launch it, gravity pulls it back. It never escapes.
S5.S5_D8_FX_C1: Exactly right, Leila. Even at maximum speed in this simulator, the projectile follows a parabolic path and returns to Earth.
S5.S5_D9_FX_C1: Getting to space isn’t just about going up. It’s about going sideways—fast enough that as you fall, Earth curves away beneath you.
S5.S5_D10_FX_C3: So... going straight up is the wrong strategy?
S5.S5_D11_FX_C1: Yes. Think about it. When you launch at a steep angle, you go high but fall back quickly. When you launch at a shallow angle, you travel farther sideways. So instead of fighting gravity by going up, we go sideways fast so that we keep missing the ground.
S5.S5_D12_FX_C1: Let me show you the thought experiment that changed everything — Newton's Cannon on a Mountain.

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: Scientist Isaac Newton imagined something extraordinary. What if you could fire a cannon from the top of a mountain with enough speed?
S6.S6_D2_FX_C3: It will still fall back down, right? Like all our projectiles?
S6.S6_D3_FX_C1: Not necessarily. Newton discovered that at just the right speed, the cannonball falls... but the Earth curves away beneath it at the same rate.
S6.S6_D4_FX_C2: Wait... so it will keep falling but never hits the ground?
S6.S6_D5_FX_C1: Exactly! That's orbit — falling sideways so fast that you keep missing the Earth. Let's test it in our simulation tool.

about.heading: Newton's Canon
about.body:
Understanding Orbital Mechanics:

  1. Parabolic Trajectory: At speeds below 4.85 mi/s, the cannonball follows a curved path and crashes back to Earth, just like projectiles on Earth.
  2. Circular Orbit: At exactly 4.85 mi/s, the cannonball falls toward Earth but moves sideways fast enough that Earth curves away beneath it, creating a stable circular orbit.
  3. Elliptical Orbit: Near to circular velocity for some higher altitude and, between circular and escape velocity, the satellite follows an elliptical path, speeding up when close to Earth and slowing down when far away.
  4. Hyperbolic Escape: At speeds above 6.96 mi/s (escape velocity), the cannonball breaks free from Earth's gravity completely and follows an open hyperbolic path into space.

help.heading: How to use Newton's Canon?
help.body:
To explore orbital mechanics:

  1. Use the Speed slider to set a custom launch velocity, then click Fire to launch a cannonball and watch its trajectory
  2. Click the preset buttons to instantly launch cannonballs at specific speeds:
    • Below 4.85 mi/s (crashes back to Earth)
    • Exactly 4.85 mi/s (circular orbit)
    • 4.85-6.96 mi/s (elliptical orbit)
    • Above 6.96 mi/s (escape trajectory)
  3. You can launch up to 5 cannonballs simultaneously to compare different trajectories
  4. Use Reset to clear all trajectories and return to the initial view

S7.S7_D1_FX_C1: Here's Newton's famous mountain with our cannon. First, let's see what happens at low speeds. Set the speed lower than 4.85 mi/s and click Fire.
S7.S7_D2_FX_C3: It curves back down and crashes into Earth. Just like our projectiles — gravity wins.
S7.S7_D3_FX_C1: Correct. At these speeds, you're still following a parabolic path. Now try something faster — set the speed greater than or equal to 4.85 mi/s and less than 6.96 mi/s.
S7.S7_D4_FX_C2: Oh! It's circling the Earth! It's not falling back — it's staying up there!
S7.S7_D5_FX_C3: Wait, it is Falling though... it's just falling towards the Earth instead of falling into it!
S7.S7_D6_FX_C1: This is orbital velocity. The cannonball falls toward Earth, but moves sideways fast enough that Earth curves away beneath it.
S7.S7_D7_FX_C1: Now, what if we go even faster? Try setting the speed greater than or equal to 6.96 mi/s and fire.
S7.S7_D8_FX_C2: The path is opening up! It's not coming back — it's escaping!
S7.S7_D9_FX_C1: That's escape velocity. At 6.96 mi/s, you break free from Earth's gravity completely.
S7.S7_D10_FX_C1: So what determines whether you crash, orbit, or escape?

question_1.option_1: Only the angle you launch at
question_1.option_2: Only the altitude of the launch

S7.S7_D11_FX_C1: Exactly. Speed is the key. But here's something interesting — these different paths aren't random. They all belong to the same mathematical family of curves. Have you noticed the shapes?
S7.S7_D12_FX_C3: The crash path curves back... the orbit is circular... and the escape path opens outward.
S7.S7_D13_FX_C2: Different curves for different speeds. Is there a pattern?
S7.S7_D14_FX_C1: There is! And it was discovered thousands of years before Newton — by ancient Greek mathematicians studying a simple geometric shape. Let me show you.

S8.S8_D1_FX_C1: Over 2,000 years ago, Greek mathematicians discovered something remarkable while studying a simple cone.
S8.S8_D2_FX_C3: A cone? So rocket science comes from... math class?
S8.S8_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. They found that by slicing a cone at different angles, you can create every single path we just saw.
S8.S8_D4_FX_C2: Wait, so the crash path, the orbit, and the escape — they're all hidden in one shape?
S8.S8_D5_FX_C1: Yes. These shapes are called conic sections. Let me show you the cone that contains all the mathematics of spaceflight.

S9_D0_FX_C9.title: 3D Cone Slicer

about.heading: 3D Cone Slicer
about.body:
Understanding Conic Sections:

  1. Circle: When the slicing plane is perfectly horizontal (0°), it creates a circular cross-section, representing circular orbits.
  2. Ellipse: When the plane is tilted slightly, the circle stretches into an oval shape, representing elliptical orbits that most satellites follow.
  3. Parabola: When the plane angle matches the cone's side angle, it creates an open curve that never closes, representing escape trajectories at exactly orbital velocity.
  4. Hyperbola: When the plane is steeper than the cone's side, it creates an even more open curve, representing escape trajectories above escape velocity.

help.heading: How to use the 3D Cone Slicer?
help.body:
To explore conic sections:

  1. Adjust the Plane Angle slider (0° to 90°) to change how the plane cuts through the cone
  2. Move the Plane Position slider (-4 to 4) to change where the plane intersects the cone
  3. Click the example buttons to see perfect examples:
    • Circle (horizontal slice)
    • Ellipse (slightly tilted slice)
    • Parabola (plane parallel to cone side)
    • Hyperbola (steep angle slice)
  4. Watch the 3D visualization to see the intersection highlighted in yellow
  5. View the mathematical equation and 2D graph of the resulting shape below

S9_D0_FX_C9.noIntersectionMessage: Plane is not intersecting with cone.

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: Here's your cone. That plane slicing through it creates different shapes. First, try clicking the Circle button to see a perfect horizontal slice.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C2: When the plane is perfectly flat, it makes a circle! That's a circular orbit, right?
S9.S9_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. But perfect circles are rare in space — most orbits are slightly stretched. Click the Ellipse button.
S9.S9_D4_FX_C3: Oh! When we tilt the plane a bit, the circle stretches into an oval shape.
S9.S9_D5_FX_C1: That's an ellipse — the shape most satellites actually follow. Now let's see the path of trajectory that comes back to Earth. Click Parabola.
S9.S9_D6_FX_C2: The shape opens up at one end! It's like... it's not closing back on itself anymore.
S9.S9_D7_FX_C1:
Perfect observation. That's what happens below orbit-velocity at our cannon's height. When you launch a cannonball at speed lower than 4.85 mi/s, it crashes and follows a parabolic path.
Now click Hyperbola to see total escape.
S9.S9_D8_FX_C3: Whoa! It opens even wider. This is what happens above 6.96 mi/s, right?
S9.S9_D9_FX_C1: Exactly. Now try adjusting the Plane Angle slider yourself. Watch how the shape transforms as you change the angle.
S9.S9_D10_FX_C2: It's amazing! Small angle changes completely transform the shape from closed to open.
S9.S9_D11_FX_C1: Now you understand the hidden connection. Every orbital path — from falling projectiles to escaping spacecraft — follows one of these conic sections.
S9.S9_D12_FX_C1: So which shape represents a satellite in stable orbit around Earth?
S9.S9_D13_FX_C1: Correct! Circles and ellipses are closed curves, which means the satellite keeps circling. Parabolas and hyperbolas are open — the object escapes and never returns.
S9.S9_D16_FX_C1: Let's see these shapes in action with real satellites around Earth.

S10.S10_D1_FX_C1: Now that you understand orbital shapes, let's explore something fascinating — different orbits have different speeds.
S10.S10_D2_FX_C2: Wait, I thought the orbit was just going fast enough sideways. Why would the speed change?
S10.S10_D3_FX_C1: Great question. The closer you are to Earth, the stronger gravity pulls, so you need more speed to stay in orbit.
S10.S10_D4_FX_C3: So, satellites that are closer to Earth orbit faster?
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: Exactly! But there's one special orbit called geosynchronous orbit where a satellite's orbital speed matches Earth's rotation speed.
S10.S10_D6_FX_C2: So satellites in geosynchronous orbit appear stationary in the sky when viewed from the ground?
S10.S10_D7_FX_C1: Yes, let me show you the difference between a fast, low orbit and geosynchronous orbit.

about.heading: About this Tool
about.body:
This interactive simulates two satellites in orbit: one in geosynchronous orbit (GEO) and another in a lower orbit.

  1. Geosynchronous Orbit (GEO):
    • In GEO, the satellite’s orbital period matches Earth’s rotation. This means the satellite stays above the same spot on the Earth’s surface
    • The satellite travels at the same speed as Earth's rotation, resulting in a period of exactly 24 hours
  2. Lower Orbits:
    • The satellite in this orbit has a smaller radius and travels faster than the one in GEO because it's closer to Earth. The shorter orbital period results in the satellite orbiting the Earth more times per day

Adjusting Orbit Radius:

You can adjust the orbit radius of the lower orbit by dragging the slider. As you decrease the radius, the satellite's orbital speed increases, causing it to complete more orbits in less time. Conversely, increasing the radius will decrease the orbital speed.

Circular Orbit Equation:

Both circular orbits can be represented using standard form of circle formula:

(x - h)2 + (y - k)2 = r2

Where (h, k) is the center, and r is radius of circular orbit.

How Speed Affects the Path:

  • Geosynchronous Satellites (GEO): These satellites are crucial for consistent communication, weather monitoring, and navigation since they stay in the same position relative to Earth’s surface and match Earth’s rotation with their orbital period of 24 hours
  • Lower Orbit Satellites: While these satellites orbit faster and provide more detailed images of Earth's surface, they cannot stay over the same location due to their shorter orbital periods. As a result, their coverage area on Earth continuously changes

help.heading: How to Find Radius of Geosynchronous Orbit
help.body:
Follow these steps to find the radius of the orbit that corresponds to a geosynchronous orbit for objects.

  • In this interactive, a geosynchronous orbit circle is represented using a purple dashed line and lower orbit which radius you can adjust is represented using a red dashed line
  • Try adjusting the radius of the red circle and see where it overlaps with the purple dashed circle (geosynchronous orbit)

interactive_data.instructions_1: Click and drag to move the coordinate system
interactive_data.instructions_2: Watch how the circle equations update
interactive_data.instructions_3: Notice that only the center point (h, k) is the center and r changes, while the radius remains constant
interactive_data.success_message: Success! You have reached geosynchronous orbit.

S11.S11_D1_FX_C1: Watch the two satellites. The purple one is in geosynchronous orbit — it orbits at the same speed as Earth's rotation speed.
S11.S11_D2_FX_C1: The red satellite is in a lower orbit. Notice how it's orbiting around Earth much faster. Now adjust the Orbit Radius slider to change the red satellite's orbit radius.
S11.S11_D3_FX_C3: The closer I bring it to Earth, the faster it's orbiting around Earth.
S11.S11_D4_FX_C2: And when I move it farther out, it slows down.
S11.S11_D5_FX_C1: Now, try matching the red orbit to the purple one. Adjust until they're at the same radius.
S11.S11_D6_FX_C3: It's orbiting at the same speed as Earth's rotation speed.
S11.S11_D7_FX_C1: That's the geosynchronous orbit — it's about 22,236 miles above Earth's surface. At this exact altitude, the orbital period equals Earth's rotation.
S11.S11_D9_FX_C1: Many communication satellites use geosynchronous orbits, so a ground dish can point in a fixed direction and never move. GPS satellites use lower, faster orbits to cover more ground quickly.
S11.S11_D10_FX_C2: So the mission determines the orbit — communication satellites stay high, while imaging satellites fly low to capture high resolution images of Earth's surface.
S11.S11_D11_FX_C3: And it's all circles and ellipses — the conic sections we saw in the cone!
S11.S11_D12_FX_C1: You're connecting all the pieces. Now let's put everything together and launch our own satellite into orbit.

S12.S12_D1_FX_C1: You've learned the theory — parabolic trajectories, Newton's Cannon, conic sections, and orbital speeds. Now it's time to apply everything.
S12.S12_D2_FX_C3: We get to launch our own satellite? For real?
S12.S12_D3_FX_C1: As real as it gets in training. You'll choose the altitude and velocity. Your satellite will either crash, orbit, or escape — based entirely on your choices.
S12.S12_D4_FX_C2: So we need to remember the circular orbit velocity and escape velocity for whatever altitude we choose?
S12.S12_D5_FX_C1: Exactly. The simulator will show you both velocities for your chosen altitude. Too slow, and gravity wins. Too fast, and you escape. Just right, and you achieve orbit.
S12.S12_D6_FX_C3: This is it. Everything we've learned comes down to this launch!
S12.S12_D7_FX_C1: Let's see if you can become rocket scientists. Launch your satellite and watch the mathematics of spaceflight come to life.

about.heading: Satellite Launch Simulator
about.body:
Understanding Orbital Mechanics:

  1. Parabolic Trajectory: Below circular velocity, the satellite follows a curved path and crashes back to Earth, demonstrating insufficient orbital speed.
  2. Circular Orbit: At exactly the circular velocity, the satellite achieves a stable circular orbit, falling around Earth forever.
  3. Elliptical Orbit: Between circular and escape velocity, the satellite follows an elliptical path, speeding up when close to Earth and slowing down when far away.
  4. Hyperbolic Escape: At or above escape velocity, the satellite breaks free from Earth's gravity and follows a hyperbolic trajectory into space.

The simulator uses two fundamental orbital mechanics formulas:

Circular Orbit Velocity:

v = GMr

Escape Velocity:

ve = 2GMR

Where:

  • v = orbital velocity
  • ve = escape velocity
  • G = universal gravitational constant
  • M = mass of the celestial body
  • r = orbital radius
  • R = radius from center of body to point of launch

help.heading: How to Use the Satellite Launch Simulator
help.body:
To explore orbital mechanics:

  1. Adjust the Orbital Insertion Altitude slider (62-1243 miles) to set launch height
  2. Modify the Insertion Velocity slider (0.0-8.08 mi/s) to set launch speed
  3. Observe how the Circular Orbit Velocity and Escape Velocity update automatically
  4. Click Launch to start the simulation and watch the satellite's trajectory
  5. Use Reset to stop the simulation and return to initial state
  6. Try different velocity combinations to see different orbit types:
    • Below circular velocity (crashes back to Earth)
    • At circular velocity (perfect circular orbit)
    • Between circular and escape velocity (elliptical orbit)
    • At or above escape velocity (hyperbolic escape)
  7. Adjust Simulation Speed (1X, 2X, 5X) to control time scale

S13.S13_D1_FX_C1: Here's your satellite launch simulator. With it, you'll test how speed at selected altitude decides whether your satellite crashes, orbits, or escapes.
S13.S13_D2_FX_C2: So this is the real math of orbits — not just guessing, but calculating.
S13.S13_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. Behind the screen is the vis-viva equation. It tells us what velocity a satellite needs at any altitude from Earth. Too little, and gravity wins. Too much, and you're gone forever.
S13.S13_D4_FX_C1: First, let's understand the challenge: every orbit you make is one of the conic sections you just studied — circle, ellipse, parabola, or hyperbola. Now let's explore them.
S13.S13_D5_FX_C1: Set your Orbital Insertion Altitude — that's how high above Earth you want to release the satellite.
S13.S13_D6_FX_C2: I can see the circular orbit velocity changing as I move the altitude! Higher altitude means slower orbital speed needed.
S13.S13_D7_FX_C1: Perfect observation. Also notice the escape velocity.
S13.S13_D8_FX_C1: Try launching your satellite with a velocity below the circular orbit velocity.
S13.S13_D9_FX_C2: It's falling back! The trajectory curves down and crashes into Earth — just like our early projectiles.
S13.S13_D10_FX_C1: That's a parabolic path — you didn't have enough sideways speed. Now reset and try launching at exactly the circular orbit velocity shown.
S13.S13_D11_FX_C3: It's orbiting! Look — it's making a perfect circle around Earth! This is what we saw in Newton's Cannon!
S13.S13_D12_FX_C2: The path closed on itself. It's falling around the Earth forever, just like Dr. Vega said!
S13.S13_D13_FX_C1: Beautiful! That's a circular orbit. Now try launching slightly faster than circular velocity but below escape velocity.
S13.S13_D14_FX_C3: Whoa! The orbit isn't a perfect circle anymore — it's stretched into an ellipse!
S13.S13_D15_FX_C1: Most real satellites follow elliptical orbits. They speed up when close to Earth and slow down when far away. Now for the ultimate test — launch at or above escape velocity.
S13.S13_D16_FX_C2: The path is opening up! It's not coming back — the satellite is escaping Earth's gravity completely!
S13.S13_D17_FX_C3: That's the hyperbola from the cone slicer! The satellite is free!
S13.S13_D18_FX_C1: At any given altitude, what determines whether a satellite achieves a stable orbit?
S13.S13_D19_FX_C1: Exactly! At any given altitude, velocity is the key factor. You've just demonstrated every conic section we studied — parabola, circle, ellipse, and hyperbola — all from one simulator.

S14.S14_D1_FX_C3: I can't believe we just launched satellites using math from thousands of years ago!
S14.S14_D2_FX_C1: Let's reflect on your journey. You started thinking space was about going up, but learned that whether getting into orbit or escaping, it's really about going sideways fast enough.
S14.S14_D3_FX_C2: Then Newton's Cannon proved orbiting is just falling around Earth instead of into it. And conic sections connected everything — circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.
S14.S14_D4_FX_C3: Every orbital path follows one of those curves. Mathematics isn't just abstract formulas — it's the language that describes reality, from projectiles to planets.
S14.S14_D5_FX_C1: You've learned what took humanity centuries to discover. Getting to space isn't about power or height — it's about understanding physics and using it perfectly.

quest_completion.subheading: You Have Completed Orbital Mechanics Training!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the Falling Into Orbit STEAMQuest!

  • You explored how parabolic trajectories govern projectile motion and discovered that speed alone cannot achieve orbit
  • You tested Newton's revolutionary thought experiment and proved that orbiting is falling sideways fast enough to continuously miss Earth
  • You uncovered conic sections hidden within a cone and learned that circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas describe every possible orbital path
  • You compared geosynchronous and low Earth orbits to understand how altitude determines orbital velocity and satellite mission design

Keep exploring how ancient mathematics predicts modern spaceflight and guides humanity's journey to the stars!

conic-sections.definition: Conic Sections are shapes created by intersecting a plane with a cone. The four types are circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

ellipse.definition: Ellipse is an oval-shaped curve, formed when a plane cuts through a cone at an angle. It has two foci and a longer axis (major axis) and a shorter axis (minor axis).

hyperbola.definition: Hyperbola is a curve formed when a plane intersects both halves of a cone. It has two branches that move away from each other and can represent paths of objects escaping gravity.

parabola.definition: Parabola is a U-shaped curve formed by slicing a cone parallel to its side. In orbital mechanics, it represents the path of an object at escape velocity.

circle.definition: A Circle is the set of all points in a plane that are a given distance, the radius, from a given point, the center, representing the path of an object in a stable orbit.

orbit.definition: Orbit is a curved path an object takes around a star, planet, or moon due to gravity. It can be circular, elliptical, or hyperbolic depending on the object's speed and trajectory.

escape-velocity.definition: Escape Velocity is the minimum speed needed for an object to break free from the gravitational pull of a planet or moon without further propulsion.

parabolic_trajectory.definition: Parabolic Trajectory is the curved path an object follows through the air under the force of gravity after it is thrown or launched.

altitude.definition: Altitude is the height at which an object is above the surface of a planet. It is measured from the ground to its position in the sky.

common.char1_description: A seasoned African American NASA mission director, wearing a professional blazer, with an analytical demeanor and authoritative presence.
common.char2_description: A young Navajo flight dynamics engineer, enthusiastic and attentive, dressed in a NASA trainee uniform, eager to apply her academic skills practically.
common.char3_description: A diplomatic Chilean-American UN advisor in a formal suit, thoughtful and poised, emphasizing international cooperation in space exploration.
common.bg1_description: Futuristic glass building with space-themed logo, set against mountain backdrop with blue sky.
common.bg2_description: Futuristic command center with large digital displays showing Earth and global data, team gathered around central console.
common.bg3_description: High-tech control room with curved wall of digital screens displaying Earth and data visualizations, lone figure monitoring operations.
common.bg4_description: Aerospace mission control room with holographic rocket display, global tracking screens, and personnel monitoring launch operations.
common.bg5_description: Futuristic data visualization center with circular central platform, multiple people observing large digital displays showing Earth and analytical information.
